" [I]568-pollack said [he]3580-the captain was a Card , that 's all , "[568-pollack] said [Pollack]568-pollack . " [I]3580-the captain 'm coming . "[3580-the captain] [He]3580-the captain appeared in [my]0-i doorway [a faint white figure]3768-a faint white figure joined [our]3769-we vehement whisperings . [We]3769-we had to buy [the captain]3580-the captain off ; [we]3769-we had to promise [him]3580-the captain ten per cent . of [our]3769-we problematical profits . [We]3769-we were to give [him]3580-the captain ten per cent . on what [we]3769-we sold the cargo for over and above [his]3580-the captain legitimate pay , and [I]0-i found in [my]0-i out - bargained and disordered state small consolation in the thought that [I]0-i , as [the Gordon - Nasmyth expedition]3771-the gordon - nasmyth expedition , was to sell the stuff to [myself]0-i as Business Organisations . And [he]3580-the captain further exasperated [me]0-i by insisting on having [our]3769-we bargain in writing . " In the form of a letter , "[3580-the captain] [he]3580-the captain insisted . " All right , "[3580-the captain] [I]0-i acquiesced , " in the form of a letter . Here goes ! Get a light ! "[0-i] " And the apology , "[3580-the captain] [he]3580-the captain said , folding up the letter . " All right , "[0-i] [I]0-i said ; " Apology . "[0-i] [My]0-i hand shook with anger as [I]0-i wrote , and afterwards [I]0-i could not sleep for hate of [him]3580-the captain . At last [I]0-i got up . [I]0-i suffered , [I]0-i found , from an unusual clumsiness . [I]0-i struck [my]0-i toe against [my]0-i cabin door , and cut [myself]0-i as [I]0-i shaved . [I]0-i found [myself]0-i at last pacing [the deck]3772-the deck under the dawn in a mood of extreme exasperation . The sun rose abruptly and splashed light blindingly into [my]0-i eyes and [I]0-i swore at the sun . [I]0-i found [myself]0-i imagining fresh obstacles with [the men]2383-the men and talking aloud in anticipatory rehearsal of the consequent row . The malaria of the quap was already in [my]0-i blood . Sooner or later the ridiculous embargo that now lies upon [all the coast eastward of [Mordet Island]207-mordet island]3774-all the coast eastward of mordet island will be lifted and the reality of the deposits of quap ascertained . [I]0-i am sure that [we]3775-our were merely taking the outcrop of a stratum of nodulated deposits that dip steeply seaward . Those heaps were merely the crumbled out contents of two irregular cavities in [the rock]6631-the rock ; they are as natural as any talus or heap of that kind , and the mud along the edge of [the water]5257-the water for miles is mixed with quap , and is radio - active and lifeless and faintly phosphorescent at night . But [the reader]4558-the reader will find the full particulars of [my]0-i impression of all this in the Geological Magazine for October , 1905 , and to that [I]0-i must refer [him]4558-the reader . There , too , [he]4558-the reader will find [my]0-i unconfirmed theories of its nature . If [I]0-i am right it is something far more significant from the scientific point of view than those incidental constituents of various rare metals , pitchblende , rutile , and the like , upon which the revolutionary discoveries of the last decade are based . Those are just little molecular centres of disintegration , of that mysterious decay and rotting of those elements , elements once regarded as the most stable things in nature . But there is something - the only word that comes near it is CANCEROUS - and that is not very near , about the whole of quap , something that creeps and lives as a disease lives by destroying ; an elemental stirring and disarrangement , incalculably maleficent and strange . This is no imaginative comparison of [mine]0-i . To [my]0-i mind radio - activity is a real disease of matter . Moreover , it is a contagious disease . It spreads . [You]3779-you bring [those debased and crumbling atoms near others]3780-those debased and crumbling atoms near others and those too presently catch the trick of swinging [themselves]3780-those debased and crumbling atoms near others out of coherent existence . It is in matter exactly what the decay of [our]3775-our old culture is in society , a loss of traditions and distinctions and assured reactions . When [I]0-i think of these inexplicable dissolvent centres that have come into being in [[our]3775-our globe]3781-our globe - these quap heaps are surely by far the largest that have yet been found in [the world]751-the world ; the rest as yet mere specks in grains and crystals - [I]0-i am haunted by a grotesque fancy of the ultimate eating away and dry - rotting and dispersal of all [[our]3775-our world]929-our world . So that while [man]1088-man still struggles and dreams [his]1088-man very substance will change and crumble from beneath [him]1088-man . [I]0-i mention this here as a queer persistent fancy . Suppose , indeed , that is to be the end of [[our]3775-our planet]3785-our planet ; no splendid climax and finale , no towering accumulation of achievements , but just - atomic decay ! [I]0-i add that to the ideas of the suffocating comet , the dark body out of space , the burning out of the sun , the distorted orbit , as a new and far more possible end - as Science can see ends - to this strange by - play of matter that [we]3775-our call human life . [I]0-i do not believe this can be the end ; [no human soul]3786-no human soul can believe in such an end and go on living , but to it science points as a possible thing , science and reason alike . If [single human beings]3787-single human beings - if [one single ricketty infant]3788-one single ricketty infant - can be born as it were by accident and die futile , why not [the whole race]3789-the whole race ? These are questions [I]0-i have never answered , that now [I]0-i never attempt to answer , but the thought of quap and its mysteries brings them back to [me]0-i . [I]0-i can witness that [the beach]2925-the beach and mud for two miles or more either way was [a lifeless beach]3791-a lifeless beach - lifeless as [I]0-i could have imagined [no tropical mud]3792-no tropical mud could ever be , and all the dead branches and leaves and rotting dead fish and so forth that drifted [ashore]3793-ashore became presently shrivelled and white . Sometimes crocodiles would come up out of the water and bask , and now and then water birds would explore the mud and rocky ribs that rose out of it , in a mood of transitory speculation . That was its utmost admiration . And the air felt at once hot and austere , dry and blistering , and altogether different the warm moist embrace that had met [us]3775-our at [our]3775-our first African landfall and to which [we]3775-our had grown accustomed . [I]0-i believe that the primary influence of the quap upon [us]3775-our was to increase the conductivity of [our]3775-our nerves , but that is a mere unjustifiable speculation on [my]0-i part . At any rate it gave a sort of east wind effect to life . [We]3775-our all became irritable , clumsy , languid and disposed to be impatient with [our]3775-our languor . [We]3775-our moored [the brig]5754-the brig to [the rocks]3795-the rocks with difficulty , and got aground on mud and decided to stick there and tow off when [we]3775-our had done - the bottom was as greasy as butter . [Our]3775-our efforts to fix up planks and sleepers in order to wheel the quap aboard were as ill - conceived as that sort of work can be - and that sort of work can at times be very ill - conceived . [The captain]3580-the captain had a superstitious fear of [his]3580-the captain hold : [he]3580-the captain became wildly gesticulatory and expository and incompetent at the bare thought of it . [His]3580-the captain shouts still echo in [my]0-i memory , becoming as each crisis approached less and less like any known tongue . But [I]0-i can not now write the history of those days of blundering and toil : of how [Milton]460-old milton , [one of [the boys]5548-the boys]3797-one of the boys , fell from a plank to [the beach]2925-the beach , thirty feet perhaps , with [his]460-old milton barrow and broke [his]460-old milton arm and [I]0-i believe a rib , of how [I]0-i and [Pollack]568-pollack set the limb and nursed [him]3580-the captain through the fever that followed , of how [one man after another]3800-one man after another succumbed to a feverish malaria , and how [I]0-i - by virtue of [my]0-i scientific reputation - was obliged to play the part of [doctor]3801-doctor and dose [them]3801-doctor with quinine , and then finding that worse than nothing , with rum and small doses of [Easton]661-easton 's Syrup , of which there chanced to be a case of bottles aboard - [Heaven]598-heaven and [Gordon - Nasmyth]562-gordon - nasmyth know why . For three long days [we]3802-we lay in misery and never shipped a barrow - load . Then , when [they]3803-they resumed , [the men]2383-the men 's hands broke out into sores . There were no gloves available ; and [I]0-i tried to get [them]2383-the men , while [they]2383-the men shovelled and wheeled , to cover [their]2383-the men hands with stockings or greased rags . [They]2383-the men would not do this on account of the heat and discomfort . This attempt of [mine]0-i did , however , direct [their]2383-the men attention to [the quap]3680-the quap as the source of [their]2383-the men illness and precipitated what in the end finished [our]3802-we lading , an informal strike . " [We]3802-we 've had enough of this , "[2383-the men] [they]2383-the men said , and [they]2383-the men meant it . [They]2383-the men came aft to say as much . [They]2383-the men cowed [the captain]3580-the captain . Through all these days the weather was variously vile , first a furnace heat under a sky of a scowling intensity of blue , then a hot fog that stuck in one 's throat like wool and turned [the men on the planks into colourless figures of giants]3807-the men on the planks into colourless figures of giants , then a wild burst of thunderstorms , mad elemental uproar and rain . Through it all , against illness , heat , confusion of mind , [one master]3808-one master impetus prevailed with [me]0-i , to keep [the shipping]3809-the shipping going , to maintain one motif at least , whatever else arose or ceased , the chuff of the spades , the squeaking and shriek of the barrows , the pluppa , pluppa , pluppa , as [the men]2383-the men came trotting along the swinging high planks , and then at last , the dollop , dollop , as the stuff shot into the hold . " Another barrow - load , thank [God]357-god ! Another fifteen hundred , or it may be two thousand pounds , for the saving of [Ponderevo]351-ponderevo ! ... "[0-i] [I]0-i found out many things about [myself]0-i and [humanity]3811-humanity in those weeks of effort behind [Mordet Island]207-mordet island . But [I]0-i hated all humanity during the time that [the quap]3680-the quap was near [me]0-i . And [my]0-i mind was pervaded , too , by a sense of urgency and by the fear that [we]3818-our should be discovered and [our]3818-our proceedings stopped . [I]0-i wanted to get out to [sea]1495-sea again - to be beating up northward with [our]3818-our plunder . "[731-my uncle] A day or so after [we]3818-our had got to work upon [the quap]3680-the quap [I]0-i found [myself]0-i so sleepless and miserable that [the ship]6552-the ship became unendurable . Just before the rush of sunrise [I]0-i borrowed [Pollack]568-pollack 's gun , walked down the planks , clambered over the quap heaps and prowled along [the beach]2925-the beach . [I]0-i went perhaps a mile and a half that day and some distance beyond [the ruins of [the old station]3835-the old station]3834-the ruins of the old station . [I]0-i became interested in the desolation about [me]0-i , and found when [I]0-i returned that [I]0-i was able to sleep for nearly an hour . It was delightful to have been alone for so [long,-no captain]3836-long,-no captain , [no Pollack]3837-no pollack , [no one]4418-no one . Accordingly [I]0-i repeated this expedition the next morning and the next until it became a custom with [me]0-i . There was little for [me]0-i to do once the digging and wheeling was organised , and so these prowlings of [mine]0-i grew longer and longer , and presently [I]0-i began to take food with [me]0-i . [I]0-i pushed these walks far beyond [the area]4779-the area desolated by [the quap]3680-the quap . On the edges of that was first [a zone of stunted vegetation]3841-a zone of stunted vegetation , then [a sort of swampy jungle that was difficult to penetrate]3842-a sort of swampy jungle that was difficult to penetrate , and then the beginnings of [the forest]3730-the forest , a scene of huge tree stems and tangled creeper ropes and roots mingled with oozy mud . Here [I]0-i used to loaf in a state between botanising and reverie - always very anxious to know what was up above in the sunlight - and here it was [I]0-i murdered [a man]718-a man . It was the most unmeaning and purposeless murder imaginable . Even as [I]0-i write down its well - remembered particulars there comes again the sense of its strangeness , its pointlessness , its incompatibility with any of the neat and definite theories [people]920-people hold about life and the meaning of [the world]751-the world . [I]0-i did this thing and [I]0-i want to tell of [my]0-i doing it , but why [I]0-i did it and particularly why [I]0-i should be held responsible for it [I]0-i can not explain . That morning [I]0-i had come upon a track in [the forest]3730-the forest , and it had occurred to [me]0-i as a disagreeable idea that this was a human pathway . [I]0-i did n't want to come upon [any human beings]3848-any human beings . The less [our]3849-our expedition saw of [the African population]3850-the african population the better for its prospects . Thus far [we]3849-our had been singularly free from native pestering . [I]0-i became aware of [him]3852-my victim perhaps forty feet off standing quite still and regarding [me]0-i . [He]3852-my victim was n't by any means [a pretty figure]3853-a pretty figure . [I]0-i have never been greedy for money , [I]0-i have never wanted to be rich , but [I]0-i felt now an immense sense of impending deprivation . [The shrubbery]1287-the shrubbery was bright with laburnum and lilac , the beds swarmed with daffodils and narcissi and with lilies of [the valley]6676-the valley in the shade . [I]3961-i sat down on the stile , staring at [it]6704-it as though [I]3961-i had never seen [that forest of scaffold poles]6705-that forest of scaffold poles , that waste of walls and bricks and plaster and shaped stones , that wilderness of broken soil and wheeling tracks and dumps before . " For this [the armies]6709-the armies drilled , for this the Law was administered and [the prisons]6710-the prisons did [their]6710-the prisons duty , for this [the millions]6711-the millions toiled and perished in suffering , in order that [a few of [us]6698-we]6712-a few of us should build [palaces]6713-palaces [we]6698-we never finished , make [billiard - rooms under [ponds]6715-ponds]6714-billiard - rooms under ponds , run imbecile walls round [irrational estates]6716-irrational estates , scorch about [the world]751-the world in [motor - cars]2907-motor - cars , devise flying - machines , play golf and a dozen such foolish games of ball , crowd into chattering dinner parties , gamble and make [our]6698-we lives one vast , dismal spectacle of witless waste ! So it struck [me]3961-i then , and for a time [I]3961-i could think of no other interpretation . This was Life ! It came to [me]3961-i like a revelation , a revelation at once incredible and indisputable of the abysmal folly of [our]6698-we being . [I]0-i found [[my]0-i uncle]731-my uncle in [[my]0-i sitting - room]4006-my sitting - room in an arm - chair , with [his]731-my uncle feet upon the fender of the gas stove , which [he]731-my uncle had lit , and now [he]731-my uncle was feebly drunken with [my]0-i whisky , and very weary in body and spirit , and inclined to be cowardly . " [I]731-my uncle lef ' [my]731-my uncle drops , "[731-my uncle] [he]731-my uncle said . [He]731-my uncle changed [his]731-my uncle clothes slowly and unwillingly . [I]0-i had to bully [him]731-my uncle , [I]0-i had almost to shove [him]731-my uncle to [the airship]4007-the airship and tuck [him]731-my uncle up upon [its]4007-the airship wicker flat . Single - handed [I]0-i made but a clumsy start ; [we]4008-we scraped along the roof of [the shed]3431-the shed and bent [a van of the propeller]4010-a van of the propeller , and for a time [I]0-i hung underneath without [his]731-my uncle offering a hand to help [me]0-i to clamber up . If it had n't been for a sort of anchoring trolley device of [Cothope]634-cothope 's , a sort of slip anchor running on a rail , [we]4008-we should never have got clear at all . The incidents of [our]4008-we flight in [Lord Roberts B]353-lord roberts b do not arrange [themselves]4011-themselves in any consecutive order . To think of that adventure is like dipping haphazard into an album of views . [One]696-one is reminded first of this and then of that . [We]4008-we were both lying down on a horizontal plate of basketwork ; for [Lord Roberts B]353-lord roberts b had none of the elegant accommodation of [a balloon]4013-a balloon . [I]0-i lay forward , and [[my]0-i uncle]731-my uncle behind [me]0-i in such a position that [he]731-my uncle could see hardly anything of [our]4008-we flight . [We]4008-we were protected from rolling over simply by netting between the steel stays . It was impossible for [us]4008-we to stand up at all ; [we]4008-we had either to lie or crawl on all fours over the basket work . Amidships were lockers made of [Watson]672-watson 's Aulite material,-and between these it was that [I]0-i had put [[my]0-i uncle]731-my uncle , wrapped in rugs . [I]0-i wore sealskin motoring boots and gloves , and a motoring fur coat over [my]0-i tweeds , and [I]0-i controlled the engine by Bowden wires and levers forward . The early part of that night 's experience was made up of warmth , of moonlit [Surrey]295-surrey and [Sussex]188-sussex landscape , and of a rapid and successful flight , ascending and swooping , and then ascending again southward . [I]0-i could not watch the clouds because [the airship]4007-the airship overhung [me]0-i ; [I]0-i could not see the stars nor gauge the meteorological happening , but it was fairly clear to [me]0-i that a wind shifting between north and northeast was gathering strength , and after [I]0-i had satisfied [myself]0-i by a series of entirely successful expansions and contractions of the real air - worthiness of [Lord Roberts B]353-lord roberts b , [I]0-i stopped the engine to save [my]0-i petrol , and let the monster drift , checking its progress by [the dim landscape below]4017-the dim landscape below . [[My]0-i uncle]731-my uncle lay quite still behind [me]0-i , saying little and staring in front of [him]731-my uncle , and [I]0-i was left to [my]0-i own thoughts and sensations . [My]0-i thoughts , whatever they were , have long since faded out of memory , and [my]0-i sensations have merged into one continuous memory of [an countryside]4019-an countryside lying , as it seemed , under snow , with square patches of dimness , white phantoms of [roads]4020-roads , [rents and pools of velvety blackness]4021-rents and pools of velvety blackness , and [lamp - jewelled houses]4022-lamp - jewelled houses . [I]0-i remember [a train]4023-a train boring its way like a hastening caterpillar of fire across [the landscape]4024-the landscape , and how distinctly [I]0-i heard its clatter . [Every town]4025-every town and [street]4026-street was buttoned with street lamps . [I]0-i came quite close to [the South Downs]296-the south downs near [Lewes]187-lewes , and all the lights were out in [the houses]4027-the houses , and [the people]1497-the people gone to bed . [We]4029-we left [the land]1147-the land a little to [the east of [Brighton]297-brighton]4031-the east of brighton , and by that time [Brighton]297-brighton was well abed . and [the brightly lit sea - front]4032-the brightly lit sea - front deserted . Then [I]0-i let out the gas chamber to its fullest extent and rose . [I]0-i like to be high above water . [I]0-i do not clearly know what happened in the night . [I]0-i think [I]0-i must have dozed , and probably [[my]0-i uncle]731-my uncle slept . [I]0-i remember that once or twice [I]0-i heard [him]731-my uncle talking in an eager , muffled voice to [himself]731-my uncle , or to an imaginary court . But there can be no doubt the wind changed right round into the east , and that [we]4029-we were carried far down [the Channel]298-the channel without any suspicion of the immense leeway [we]4029-we were making . [I]0-i remember the kind of stupid perplexity with which [I]0-i saw the dawn breaking over [a grey waste of water]4034-a grey waste of water , below , and realised that something was wrong . [I]0-i was so stupid that it was only after the sunrise [I]0-i really noticed the trend of the foam caps below , and perceived [we]4029-we were in a severe easterly gale . Even then , instead of heading southeasterly , [I]0-i set the engine going , headed south , and so continued a course that must needs have either just hit [Ushant]299-ushant , or carry [us]4029-we over [the Bay of Biscay]281-the bay of biscay . [I]0-i thought [I]0-i was [east of [Cherbourg]300-cherbourg]4035-east of cherbourg , when [I]0-i was far to the west and stopped [my]0-i engine in that belief , and then set it going again . [I]0-i did actually sight [the coast of [Brittany]294-brittany]4036-the coast of brittany to the southeast in the late afternoon , and that it was woke [me]0-i up to the gravity of [our]4029-we position . [I]0-i discovered it by accident in [the southeast]4037-the southeast , when [I]0-i was looking for it in [the southwest]4038-the southwest . [I]0-i turned about east and faced the wind for some time , and finding [I]0-i had no chance in its teeth , went high , where it seemed less violent , and tried to make a course southeast . It was only then that [I]0-i realised what a gale [I]0-i was in . [I]0-i had been going westward , and perhaps even in gusts north of west , at a pace of fifty or sixty miles an hour . Then [I]0-i began what [I]0-i suppose would be called a Fight against the east wind . [One]696-one calls it a Fight , but it was really almost as unlike a fight as plain sewing . The wind tried to drive [me]0-i westwardly , and [I]0-i tried to get as much as [I]0-i could eastwardly , with the wind beating and rocking [us]4029-we irregularly , but by no means unbearably , for about twelve hours . [My]0-i hope lay in the wind abating , and [our]4029-we keeping in the air and eastward of [Finisterre]301-finisterre until it did , and the chief danger was the exhaustion of [our]4029-we petrol . It was a long and anxious and almost meditative time ; [we]4029-we were fairly warm , and only slowly getting hungry , and except that [[my]0-i uncle]731-my uncle grumbled a little and produced some philosophical reflections , and began to fuss about having a temperature , [we]4029-we talked very little . [I]0-i was tired and sulky , and chiefly worried about the engine . [I]0-i had to resist a tendency to crawl back and look at it . [I]0-i did not care to risk contracting [[our]4029-we gas chamber]4041-our gas chamber for fear of losing gas . Nothing was less like a fight . [I]0-i know that in popular magazines , and so forth , all such occasions as this are depicted in terms of hysteria . [Captains]4042-captains save [[their]4042-captains ships]4043-their ships engineers complete [[their]4042-captains bridges]4044-their bridges , [generals]4045-generals conduct [their]4045-generals battles , in a state of dancing excitement , foaming recondite technicalities at the lips . [I]0-i suppose that sort of thing works up [the reader]4558-the reader , but so far as it professes to represent reality , [I]0-i am convinced it is all childish nonsense , [schoolboys of fifteen]4047-schoolboys of fifteen , [girls of eighteen]4048-girls of eighteen , and [literary men]4049-literary men all [their]4049-literary men lives , may have these squealing fits , but [my]0-i own experience is that most exciting scenes are not exciting , and most of the urgent moments in life are met by [steady - headed men]4050-steady - headed men . Neither [I]0-i nor [[my]0-i uncle]731-my uncle spent the night in ejaculations , nor in humorous allusions , nor any of these things . [We]4052-we remained lumpish . [[My]0-i uncle]731-my uncle stuck in [his]731-my uncle place and grumbled about [his]731-my uncle stomach , and occasionally rambled off into expositions of [his]731-my uncle financial position and denunciations of [Neal]668-neal - [he]731-my uncle certainly struck out one or two good phrases for [Neal]668-neal - and [I]0-i crawled about at rare intervals in a vague sort of way and grunted , and [our]4052-we basketwork creaked continually , and the wind on [[our]4052-we quarter]3727-our quarter made a sort of ruffled flapping in the wall of [the gas chamber]4055-the gas chamber . For all [our]4052-we wraps [we]4052-we got frightfully cold as the night wore on . [I]0-i must have dozed , and it was still dark when [I]0-i realised with a start that [we]4052-we were nearly due south of , and a long way from , a regularly - flashing lighthouse , standing out before the glow of [some great town]4056-some great town , and then that the thing that had awakened [me]0-i was the cessation of [our]4052-we engine , and that [we]4052-we were driving back to the west . Then , indeed , for a time [I]0-i felt the grim thrill of life . [I]0-i crawled forward to the cords of the release valves , made [[my]0-i uncle]731-my uncle crawl forward too , and let out the gas until [we]4052-we were falling down through the air like a clumsy glider towards the vague greyness that was land . Something must have intervened here that [I]0-i have forgotten . [I]0-i saw the lights of [Bordeaux]302-bordeaux when it was quite dark , a nebulous haze against black ; of that [I]0-i am reasonably sure . But certainly [our]4052-we fall took place in the cold , uncertain light of early dawn . [I]0-i am , at least , equally sure of that . And [Mimizan]303-mimizan , near where [we]4052-we dropped , is fifty miles from [Bordeaux]302-bordeaux , whose harbour lights [I]0-i must have seen . [I]0-i remember coming down at last with a curious indifference , and actually rousing [myself]0-i to steer . But the actual coming to earth was exciting enough . [I]0-i remember [our]4052-we prolonged dragging landfall , and the difficulty [I]0-i had to get clear , and how a gust of wind caught [Lord Roberts B]353-lord roberts b as [[my]0-i uncle]731-my uncle stumbled away from the ropes and litter , and dropped [me]0-i heavily , and threw [me]0-i on to [my]0-i knees . Then came the realisation that the monster was almost consciously disentangling itself for escape , and then the light leap of its rebound . The rope slipped out of reach of [my]0-i hand . [I]0-i remember running knee - deep in [a salt pool]4059-a salt pool in hopeless pursuit of [the airship]4007-the airship . As it dragged and rose seaward , and how only after it had escaped [my]0-i uttermost effort to recapture it , did [I]0-i realise that this was quite the best thing that could have happened . It drove swiftly over [the sandy dunes]4061-the sandy dunes , lifting and falling , and was hidden by a clump of windbitten trees . Then it reappeared much further off , and still receding . It soared for a time , and sank slowly , and after that [I]0-i saw it no more . [I]0-i suppose it fell into [the sea]1422-the sea and got wetted with salt water and heavy , and so became deflated and sank . It was never found , and there was never a report of [anyone]3938-anyone seeing [it]4007-the airship after [it]4007-the airship escaped from [me]0-i . But if [I]0-i find it hard to tell the story of [our]4064-we long flight through the air overseas , at least that dawn in [France]192-france stands cold and clear and full . [I]0-i see again almost as if [I]0-i saw once more with [my]0-i bodily eyes the ridges of sand rising behind ridges of sand , grey and cold and black - browed , with an insufficient grass . [I]0-i feel again the clear , cold chill of dawn , and hear the distant barking of a dog . [I]0-i find [myself]0-i asking again , " What shall [we]4064-we do now ? "[0-i] and trying to scheme with brain tired beyond measure . At first [[my]0-i uncle]731-my uncle occupied [my]0-i attention . [He]731-my uncle was shivering a good deal , and it was all [I]0-i could do to resist [my]0-i desire to get [him]731-my uncle into a comfortable bed at once . But [I]0-i wanted to appear plausibly in [this part of [the world]751-the world]4066-this part of the world . It was dark night when [I]0-i left [his]4139-a fattish , stolid man in grey alpaca deathbed and went back to [[my]0-i own inn]4164-my own inn down [the straggling street of [Luzon]310-luzon]4165-the straggling street of luzon . That return to [[my]0-i inn]4166-my inn sticks in [my]0-i memory also as a thing apart , as an experience apart . Within was a subdued bustle of [women]1391-women , a flitting of lights , and the doing of petty offices to that queer , exhausted thing that had once been [[my]0-i active and urgent little uncle]4168-my active and urgent little uncle . For [me]0-i [those offices]4169-those offices were irksome and impertinent . [I]0-i slammed the door , and went out into the warm , foggy drizzle of [the village street]4170-the village street lit by blurred specks of light in great voids of darkness , and never [a soul abroad]4171-a soul abroad . That warm veil of fog produced an effect of vast seclusion . [The very houses by the roadside]4172-the very houses by the roadside peered through [it]4173-it as if from [another world]5788-another world . The stillness of the night was marked by an occasional remote baying of dogs ; all [these people]712-these people kept dogs because of [the near neighbourhood of the frontier]4176-the near neighbourhood of the frontier . Death ! It was one of those rare seasons of relief , when for a little time one walks a little outside of and beside life . [I]0-i felt as [I]0-i sometimes feel after the end of a play . [I]0-i saw the whole business of [[my]0-i uncle]731-my uncle 's life as something familiar and completed . It was done , like a play one leaves , like a book one closes . [I]0-i thought of the push and the promotions , the noise of [London]9-london , the crowded , various company of people through which [our]4178-we lives had gone , the public meetings , the excitements , the dinners and disputations , and suddenly it appeared to [me]0-i that none of these things existed . It came to [me]0-i like a discovery that none of these things existed . Before and after [I]0-i have thought and called life a phantasmagoria , but never have [I]0-i felt its truth as [I]0-i did that night .... [We]4178-we had parted ; [we]4178-we two who had kept [company so long]4179-company so long had parted . But there was , [I]0-i knew , no end to [him]731-my uncle or [me]0-i . [He]731-my uncle had died a dream death , and ended a dream ; [his]731-my uncle pain dream was over . It seemed to [me]0-i almost as though [I]0-i had died , too . What did it matter , since it was unreality , all of it , the pain and desire , the beginning and the end ? There was no reality except [this solitary road]4180-this solitary road , [this quite solitary road]4181-this quite solitary road , along which one went rather puzzled , rather tired .... Part of the fog became a big mastiff that came towards [me]0-i and stopped and slunk round [me]0-i , growling , barked gruffly , and shortly and presently became fog again . " Love , like everything else in this immense process of social disorganisation in which [we]6840-we live , is a thing adrift , a fruitless thing broken away from its connexions . [I]409-beatrice tell of this love affair here because of its irrelevance , because it is so remarkable that it should mean nothing , and be nothing except itself . It glows in [my]409-beatrice memory like some bright casual flower starting up amidst the debris of a catastrophe . For nearly a fortnight [we]6840-we two met and made love together . Once more this mighty passion , that [our]6840-we aimless civilisation has fettered and maimed and sterilised and debased , gripped [me]409-beatrice and filled [me]409-beatrice with passionate delights and solemn joys - that were all , [you]6841-you know , futile and purposeless . Once more [I]409-beatrice had the persuasion "[409-beatrice] This matters . Nothing else matters so much as this . " [We]6840-we were both infinitely grave in such happiness as [we]6840-we had . [I]4212-i do not remember any laughter at all between [us]6840-we . Twelve days it lasted from that encounter in [[my]4212-i chalet]6824-my chalet until [our]6840-we parting . Except at the end , they were days of supreme summer , and there was a waxing moon . [We]6840-we met recklessly day by day . [We]6840-we were so intent upon each other at first so intent upon expressing [ourselves]6840-we to [each other]1240-each other , and getting at [each other]1240-each other , that [we]6840-we troubled very little about the appearance of [our]6840-we relationship . [We]6840-we met almost openly .... [We]6840-we talked of ten thousand things , and of [ourselves]6840-we . [We]6840-we loved . [We]6840-we made love . There is no prose of [mine]4212-i that can tell of hours transfigured . The facts are nothing . Everything [we]6840-we touched , the meanest things , became glorious . "[4254-i] [Yours]4254-i , " [she]1864-a woman said , in a weary unimpassioned voice ; "[4254-i] all that [I]0-i had - such as it was . Will [you]4254-i forget ? " "[4254-i] Never , " [I]4254-i answered . "[4254-i] Never a touch or a word of it ? " "[4254-i] No . " "[4254-i] [You]4254-i will , " [she]1864-a woman said . [We]4257-we looked at [one another]1140-one another in silence , and [her]1864-a woman face full of fatigue and misery . What could [I]4254-i do ? What was there to do ? "[4254-i] [I]0-i wish- " [I]4254-i said , and stopped . "[4254-i] Good - bye . " That should have been the last [I]4254-i saw of [her]1864-a woman , but , indeed , [I]4254-i was destined to see [her]1864-a woman once again . Two days after [I]4254-i was at [Lady Grove]203-lady grove , [I]4254-i forget altogether upon what errand , and as [I]4254-i walked back to [the station]4654-the station believing [her]1864-a woman to be gone away [she]1864-a woman came upon [me]4254-i , and [she]1864-a woman was riding with [Carnaby]608-carnaby , just as [I]4254-i had seen [them]6880-them first . [The encounter]6881-the encounter jumped upon [us]6880-them unprepared . [She]1864-a woman rode by , [her]1864-a woman eyes dark in [her]1864-a woman white face , and scarcely noticed [me]4254-i . [She]1864-a woman winced and grew stiff at the sight of [me]4254-i and bowed [her]1864-a woman head . But [Carnaby]608-carnaby , because [he]608-carnaby thought [I]4254-i was [a broken and discomfited man]6882-a broken and discomfited man , saluted [me]4254-i with an easy friendliness , and shouted some genial commonplace to [me]4254-i . [They]6880-them passed out of sight and left [me]4254-i by the roadside .... And then , indeed , [I]4254-i tasted the ultimate bitterness of life . For the first time [I]4254-i felt utter futility , and was wrung by emotion that begot no action , by shame and pity beyond words . [I]4254-i had parted from [her]1864-a woman dully and [I]4254-i had seen [[my]4254-i uncle]731-my uncle break and die with dry eyes and a steady mind , but this chance sight of [my]4254-i lost [Beatrice]409-beatrice brought [me]4254-i to tears . [My]4254-i face was wrung , and tears came pouring down [my]4254-i cheeks . All the magic [she]1864-a woman had for [me]4254-i had changed to wild sorrow . "[4254-i] Oh [God]357-god ! " [I]4254-i cried , "[4254-i] this is too much , " and turned [my]4254-i face after [her]1864-a woman and made appealing gestures to the beech trees and cursed at fate . [I]4254-i wanted to do preposterous things , to pursue [her]1864-a woman , to save [her]1864-a woman , to turn life back so that [she]1864-a woman might begin again . [I]4254-i wonder what would have happened had [I]4254-i overtaken [them]6884-them in pursuit , breathless with running , uttering incoherent words , weeping , expostulatory . [I]4254-i came near to doing that . There was nothing in [earth]4818-earth or [heaven]6886-heaven to respect [my]4254-i curses or weeping . In the midst of it [a man who had been trimming the opposite hedge]6887-a man who had been trimming the opposite hedge appeared and stared at [me]4254-i . Abruptly , ridiculously , [I]4254-i dissembled before [him]6887-a man who had been trimming the opposite hedge and went on and caught [my]4254-i train .... But the pain [I]4254-i felt then [I]4254-i have felt a hundred times ; it is with [me]4254-i as [I]4254-i write . It haunts this book , [I]4254-i see , that is what haunts this book , from end to end . [I]4254-i have tried throughout all this story to tell things as they happened to [me]4254-i . In the beginning - the sheets are still here on the table , grimy and dogs - eared and old - looking - [I]4254-i said [I]4254-i wanted to tell [MYSELF]4254-i and the world in which [I]4254-i found [myself]4254-i , and [I]4254-i have done [my]4254-i best . But whether [I]4254-i have succeeded [I]4254-i can not imagine . All this writing is grey now and dead and trite and unmeaning to [me]4254-i ; some of it [I]4254-i know by heart . [I]4254-i am [the last person to judge it]6888-the last person to judge it . As [I]4254-i turn over the big pile of manuscript before [me]4254-i certain things become clearer to [me]4254-i , and particularly the immense inconsequences of [my]4254-i experiences . It is , [I]4254-i see now that [I]4254-i have it all before [me]4254-i , a story of activity and urgency and sterility . [I]4254-i have called it Tono - Bungay , but [I]4254-i had far better have called it Waste . [I]4254-i have told of childless [Marion]485-marion , of [[my]4254-i childless aunt]6889-my childless aunt , of [Beatrice]409-beatrice wasted and wasteful and futile . What hope is there for [a people whose women]6890-a people whose women become fruitless ? [I]4254-i think of all the energy [I]4254-i have given to vain things . [I]4254-i think of [my]4254-i industrious scheming with [[my]4254-i uncle]731-my uncle , of [Crest Hill]205-crest hill 's vast cessation , of [his]731-my uncle resonant strenuous career . [Ten thousand men]6892-ten thousand men have envied [him]731-my uncle and wished to live as [he]731-my uncle lived . It is all one spectacle of forces running to waste , of [people who use and do not replace]6893-people who use and do not replace , the story of [a country hectic with a wasting aimless fever of trade and money - making and pleasure - seeking]6894-a country hectic with a wasting aimless fever of trade and money - making and pleasure - seeking . And now [I]4254-i build [destroyers]6895-destroyers ! [Other people]3161-other people may see [this country]3037-this country in other terms ; this is how [I]4254-i have seen it . In some early chapter in this heap [I]4254-i compared all [our]6898-our present colour and abundance to October foliage before the frosts nip down the leaves . That [I]4254-i still feel was a good image . Perhaps [I]4254-i see wrongly . It may be [I]4254-i see decay all about [me]4254-i because [I]4254-i am , in a sense , decay . To others it may be a scene of achievement and construction radiant with hope . [I]4254-i , too , have a sort of hope , but it is a remote hope , a hope that finds no promise in [this Empire]6899-this empire or in any of the great things of [our]6898-our time . How they will look in history [I]4254-i do not know , how time and chance will prove them [I]4254-i can not guess ; that is how [they]6895-destroyers have mirrored [themselves]6895-destroyers on one contemporary mind . Concurrently with writing the last chapter of this book [I]4254-i have been much engaged by the affairs of a new destroyer [we]6898-our have completed . It has been an oddly complementary alternation of occupations . Three weeks or so ago this novel had to be put aside in order that [I]4254-i might give all [my]4254-i time day and night to the fitting and finishing of the engines . Last Thursday X 2 , for so [we]6898-our call [her]6900-her , was done and [I]4254-i took [her]6900-her down [the Thames]7-the thames and went out nearly to [Texel]319-texel for a trial of speed . It is curious how at times [one]696-one 's impressions will all fuse and run together into a sort of unity and become continuous with things that have hitherto been utterly alien and remote . That rush down [the river]1421-the river became mysteriously connected with this book . As [I]4254-i passed down [the Thames]7-the thames [I]4254-i seemed in a new and parallel manner to be passing [all England]1-england in review . [I]4254-i saw it then as [I]4254-i had wanted [[my]4254-i readers]6903-my readers to see it . The thought came to [me]4254-i slowly as [I]4254-i picked [my]4254-i way through [the Pool]6904-the pool ; it stood out clear as [I]4254-i went dreaming into the night out upon [the wide North Sea]321-the wide north sea . It was n't so much thinking at the time as a sort of photographic thought that came and grew clear . [X2]683-x2 went ripping through the dirty oily water as scissors rip through canvas , and the front of [my]4254-i mind was all intent with getting [her]683-x2 through under [the bridges]6905-the bridges and in and out among [the steam - boats]6906-the steam - boats and [barges]1423-barges and [rowing - boats]6908-rowing - boats and [piers]6909-piers . [I]4254-i lived with [my]4254-i hands and eyes hard ahead . [I]4254-i thought nothing then of any appearances but obstacles , but for all that the back of [my]4254-i mind took the photographic memory of it complete and vivid .... "[4254-i] This , " it came to [me]4254-i , "[4254-i] is [England]1-england . That is what [I]0-i wanted to give in [my]0-i book . This ! " [We]6910-we started in the late afternoon . [We]6910-we throbbed out of [[our]6910-we yard]6911-our yard above [Hammersmith Bridge]322-hammersmith bridge , fussed about for a moment , and headed down stream . [We]6910-we came at an easy rush down [Craven Reach]323-craven reach , past [Fulham]324-fulham and [Hurlingham]325-hurlingham , past [the long stretches of muddy meadow And muddy suburb to [Battersea]121-battersea and [Chelsea]326-chelsea]6912-the long stretches of muddy meadow and muddy suburb to battersea and chelsea , round the cape of tidy frontage that is [Grosvenor Road]327-grosvenor road and under [Vauxhall Bridge]328-vauxhall bridge , and [Westminster]90-westminster opened before [us]6910-we . [We]6910-we cleared [a string of coal barges]6913-a string of coal barges and there on the left in the October sunshine stood [the Parliament houses]6914-the parliament houses , and the flag was flying and [Parliament]639-parliament was sitting . [I]4258-i saw it at the time unseeingly ; afterwards it came into [my]4258-i mind as the centre of the whole broad panoramic effect of that afternoon . The stiff square lace of [Victorian Gothic]329-victorian gothic with its Dutch clock of [a tower]6915-a tower came upon [me]4258-i suddenly and stared and whirled past in a slow half pirouette and became still , [I]4258-i know , behind [me]4258-i as if watching [me]4258-i recede . "[4258-i] Are n't [you]4258-i going to respect [me]0-i , then ? " it seemed to say . Not [I]4258-i ! There in [that great pile of Victorian architecture]6916-that great pile of victorian architecture [the landlords]4772-the landlords and [the lawyers]6918-the lawyers , [the bishops]3114-the bishops , [the railway men]6920-the railway men and [the magnates of commerce]6921-the magnates of commerce go to and fro - in [their]4772-the landlords incurable tradition of commercialised [Bladesovery]330-bladesovery , of [meretricious gentry]6922-meretricious gentry and [nobility sold for riches]6923-nobility sold for riches . [I]4258-i have been near enough to know . [The Irish]6924-the irish and [the Labour - men]6925-the labour - men run about among [their]4772-the landlords feet , making a fuss , effecting little , [they]4772-the landlords 've got no better plans that [I]4258-i can see . Respect it indeed ! There 's a certain paraphernalia of dignity , but whom does it deceive ? [The King]5878-the king comes down in [a gilt coach]6927-a gilt coach to open the show and wears long robes and a crown ; and there 's a display of stout and slender legs in white stockings and stout and slender legs in black stockings and [artful old gentlemen]6928-artful old gentlemen in ermine . [I]4258-i was reminded of one congested afternoon [I]4258-i had spent with [[my]4258-i aunt]1458-my aunt amidst a cluster of [agitated women]6930-agitated women 's hats in [the Royal Gallery of [the House of Lords]4489-the house of lords]6931-the royal gallery of the house of lords and how [I]4258-i saw [the King]5878-the king going to open Parliament , and [the Duke of [Devonshire]78-devonshire looking like [a gorgeous pedlar]6934-a gorgeous pedlar and terribly bored with the cap of maintenance on a tray before [him]5878-the king hung by slings from [his]5878-the king shoulder]684-the duke of devonshire looking like a gorgeous pedlar and terribly bored with the cap of maintenance on a tray before him hung by slings from his shoulder . A wonderful spectacle ! It is quaint , no doubt , [this England]6935-this england - it is even dignified in places - and full of mellow associations . That does not alter the quality of the realities these robes conceal . The realities are greedy trade , base profit - seeking , bold advertisement ; and kingship and chivalry , spite of this wearing of treasured robes , are as dead among it all as that crusader [[my]4258-i uncle]731-my uncle championed against the nettles outside [the Duffield church]6937-the duffield church . [I]4258-i have thought much of that bright afternoon 's panorama . To run down [the Thames]7-the thames so is to run [one]696-one 's hand over the pages in the book of [England]1-england from end to end . One begins in [Craven Reach]323-craven reach and it is as if one were in [the heart of [old England]6940-old england]6939-the heart of old england . Behind [us]6941-us are [Kew]163-kew and [Hampton Court]109-hampton court with [their]109-hampton court memories of [Kings]6942-kings and [Cardinals]686-cardinals , and one runs at first between [Fulham]324-fulham 's episcopal garden parties and [[Hurlingham]325-hurlingham 's playground]6943-hurlingham 's playground for the sporting instinct of [[our]6941-us race]4182-our race . The whole effect is English . There is space , there are old trees and all the best qualities of the home - land in that upper reach . [Putney]331-putney , too , looks [Anglican]332-anglican on a dwindling scale . And then for a stretch [the newer developments]6945-the newer developments slop over , one misses [Bladesover]4-bladesover and there come first squalid stretches of [mean homes]6946-mean homes right and left and then [the dingy industrialism of [the south side]4745-the south side]6947-the dingy industrialism of the south side , and on the north bank the polite long front of [nice houses]6949-nice houses , [[artistic , literary , administrative people]6950-artistic , literary , administrative people 's residences]6951-artistic , literary , administrative people 's residences , that stretches from [Cheyne Walk]333-cheyne walk nearly to [Westminster]90-westminster and hides a wilderness of [slums]6952-slums . What a long slow crescendo that is , mile after mile , with [the houses]4027-the houses crowding closelier , the multiplying succession of [church towers]6954-church towers , the architectural moments , [the successive bridges]6955-the successive bridges , until [you]6956-you come out into the second movement of the piece with [[Lambeth]334-lambeth 's old palace]6957-lambeth 's old palace under [[your]6956-you quarter]6958-your quarter and [the houses of [Parliament]639-parliament on [your]6956-you bow]6959-the houses of parliament on your bow ! [Westminster Bridge]336-westminster bridge is ahead of [you]6956-you then , and through it [you]6956-you flash , and in a moment [the round - faced clock tower]6960-the round - faced clock tower cranes up to peer at [you]6956-you again and [New Scotland Yard]337-new scotland yard squares at [you]6956-you , a fat beef - eater of [a policeman]2892-a policeman disguised miraculously as [a Bastille]6962-a bastille . The northward skyline grows more intricate and pleasing , and more and more does one thank [God]357-god for [Wren]688-wren . [Somerset House]92-somerset house is as picturesque as the civil war , [one]696-one is reminded again of the original [England]1-england , [one]696-one feels in the fretted sky the quality of [Restoration Lace]338-restoration lace . And then comes [[Astor]689-astor 's strong box]6972-astor 's strong box and [the lawyers ' Inns]6973-the lawyers ' inns . ( [I]4258-i had a passing memory of [myself]4258-i there , how once [I]4258-i had trudged along [the Embankment]5337-the embankment westward , weighing [[my]4258-i uncle]731-my uncle 's offer of three hundred pounds a year .... ) Through [that central essential [London]9-london reach [I]4258-i drove]6976-that central essential london reach i drove , and [X2]683-x2 bored [her]683-x2 nose under the foam regardless of it all like a black hound going through reeds - on what trail even [I]4258-i who made [her]683-x2 can not tell . And in this reach , too , [one first]6977-one first meets the seagulls and is reminded of [the sea]1422-the sea . Blackfriars one takes - just under [these two bridges]6979-these two bridges and just between [them]6979-these two bridges is the finest bridge moment in [the world]751-the world - and behold , soaring up , hanging in the sky over a rude tumult of [warehouses]6981-warehouses , over a jostling competition of [traders]6982-traders , irrelevantly beautiful and altogether remote , [Saint Paul 's]62-saint paul 's ! "[4258-i] Of course ! " [one]696-one says , "[4258-i] [Saint Paul 's]62-saint paul 's ! " It is the very figure of whatever fineness the old Anglican culture achieved , detached , [a more dignified and chastened Saint Peter 's]6984-a more dignified and chastened saint peter 's , colder , greyer , but still ornate ; it has never been over thrown , never disavowed , only [the tall warehouses]6985-the tall warehouses and all the roar of traffic have forgotten it , [every one]1214-every one has forgotten it ; [the steamships]6987-the steamships , [the barges]6988-the barges , go heedlessly by regardless of it , intricacies of telephone wires and poles cut blackly into its thin mysteries , and presently , when in a moment the traffic permits [you]6989-you and [you]6989-you look round for it , it has dissolved like a cloud into the grey blues of the [London]9-london sky . And then the traditional and ostensible [England]1-england falls from [you]6989-you altogether . The third movement begins , the last great movement in the [London]9-london symphony , in which the trim scheme of the old order is altogether dwarfed and swallowed up . Comes [London Bridge]339-london bridge , and [the great warehouses]6990-the great warehouses tower up about [you]6989-you , waving stupendous cranes , the gulls circle and scream in [your]6989-you ears , [large ships]6991-large ships lie among [their]6991-large ships lighters , and one is in [the port of [the world]751-the world]6992-the port of the world . Again and again in this book [I]4258-i have written of [England]1-england as a feudal scheme overtaken by fatty degeneration and stupendous accidents of hypertrophy . For the last time [I]4258-i must strike that note as the memory of [the dear neat little sunlit ancient Tower of [London]9-london]6994-the dear neat little sunlit ancient tower of london lying away in a gap among [the warehouses]6995-the warehouses comes back to [me]4258-i , that little accumulation of [buildings]4853-buildings so provincially pleasant and dignified , overshadowed by [the vulgarest , most typical exploit of modern [England]1-england]6997-the vulgarest , most typical exploit of modern england , the sham Gothic casings to the ironwork of [the Tower Bridge]340-the tower bridge . [That Tower Bridge]340-the tower bridge is the very balance and confirmation of [Westminster]90-westminster 's dull pinnacles and [tower]6998-tower . [That sham Gothic bridge]6999-that sham gothic bridge ; in the very gates of [[our]7000-our mother]3720-our mother of change , [the Sea]342-the sea ! But after that one is in [a world of accident and nature]7002-a world of accident and nature . For the third part of the panorama of [London]9-london is beyond all law , order , and precedence ; it is [the seaport]7003-the seaport and [the sea]1422-the sea . One goes down the widening reaches through a monstrous variety of shipping , [great steamers]7005-great steamers , [great sailing - ships]7006-great sailing - ships , trailing the flags of all [the world]751-the world , a monstrous confusion of lighters , [witches]7008-witches ' conferences of [brown - sailed barges]7009-brown - sailed barges , wallowing tugs , a tumultuous crowding and jostling of cranes and spars , and [wharves and stores]7010-wharves and stores , and assertive inscriptions . Huge vistas of [dock]7011-dock open right and left of one , and here and there beyond and amidst it all are [church towers]6954-church towers , [little patches of indescribably old - fashioned and worn - out houses]7013-little patches of indescribably old - fashioned and worn - out houses , [riverside pubs]7014-riverside pubs and the like , vestiges of [townships that were long since torn to fragments and submerged in these new growths]7015-townships that were long since torn to fragments and submerged in these new growths . And amidst it all no plan appears , no intention , no comprehensive desire . That is the very key of it all . Each day [one]696-one feels that the pressure of commerce and traffic grew , grew insensibly monstrous , and first [this man]3681-this man made [a wharf]7018-a wharf and that erected a crane , and then [this company]7019-this company set to work and then that , and so [they]7019-this company jostled together to make this unassimilable enormity of traffic . Through it [we]7020-we dodged and drove eager for [the high seas]7021-the high seas . [I]4258-i remember how [I]4258-i laughed aloud at the glimpse of the name of [a [London]9-london County Council steamboat that ran across [me]4258-i]7022-a london county council steamboat that ran across me . [Caxton]343-caxton [it]343-caxton was called , and another was [Pepys]196-pepys , and another was [Shakespeare]572-shakespeare . [They]7019-this company seemed so wildly out of place , splashing about in that confusion . [One]696-one wanted to take [them]7019-this company out and wipe [them]7019-this company and put [them]7019-this company back in [[some English gentleman]7024-some english gentleman 's library]7025-some english gentleman 's library . Everything was alive about [them]7019-this company , flashing , splashing , and passing , [ships]837-ships moving , tugs panting , hawsers taut , barges going down with [men toiling at the sweeps]7027-men toiling at the sweeps , the water all a - swirl with the wash of shipping , scaling into millions of little wavelets , curling and frothing under the whip of the unceasing wind . Past it all [we]7028-we drove . And at [Greenwich]344-greenwich to the south , [you]7029-you know , there stands [a fine stone frontage where all the victories]7030-a fine stone frontage where all the victories are recorded in [a Painted Hall]7031-a painted hall , and beside [it]7030-a fine stone frontage where all the victories is the "[4258-i] Ship " where once upon a time [those gentlemen of [Westminster]90-westminster]4259-those gentlemen of westminster used to have an annual dinner - before [the port of [London]9-london]4260-the port of london got too much for [them]4259-those gentlemen of westminster altogether . [The old facade of [the Hospital]4262-the hospital]4261-the old facade of the hospital was just warming to the sunset as [we]4263-we went by , and after that , right and left , [the river]1421-the river opened , the sense of [the sea]1422-the sea increased and prevailed , reach after reach from [Northfleet]345-northfleet to [the Nore]346-the nore . And out [you]4266-you come at last with the sun behind [you]4266-you into [the eastern sea]4267-the eastern sea . [You]4266-you speed up and tear the oily water louder and faster , siroo , siroo - swish - siroo , and [the hills of [Kent]8-kent]4268-the hills of kent - over which [I]0-i once fled from the Christian teachings of [Nicodemus Frapp]420-nicodemus frapp - fall away on the right hand and [Essex]347-essex on the left . [They]4269-they fall away and vanish into blue haze , and [the tall slow ships behind [the tugs]4271-the tugs]4270-the tall slow ships behind the tugs , [scarce moving ships]4272-scarce moving ships and wallowing sturdy tugs , are all wrought of wet gold as one goes frothing by . [They]4269-they stand out , bound on strange missions of life and death , to the killing of men in [unfamiliar lands]4273-unfamiliar lands . And now behind [us]4263-we is blue mystery and the phantom flash of unseen lights , and presently even these are gone , and [I]0-i and [[my]0-i destroyer]4274-my destroyer tear out to the unknown across [a great grey space]4275-a great grey space . [We]4263-we tear into the great spaces of the future and the turbines fall to talking in unfamiliar tongues . Out to the open [we]4263-we go , to windy freedom and trackless ways . Light after light goes down . [England]1-england and [the Kingdom]1681-the kingdom , [Britain]152-great britain and [the Empire]4277-the empire , [the old prides]4278-the old prides and the old devotions , glide abeam , astern , sink down upon the horizon , pass - pass . [The river]1421-the river passes - [London]9-london passes , [England]1-england passes ... This is the note [I]0-i have tried to emphasise , the note that sounds clear in [my]0-i mind when [I]0-i think of anything beyond the purely personal aspects of [my]0-i story . It is a note of crumbling and confusion , of change and seemingly aimless swelling , of a bubbling up and medley of futile loves and sorrows . But through the confusion sounds another note . Through the confusion something drives , something that is at once human achievement and the most inhuman of all existing things . Something comes out of it .... How can [I]0-i express the values of a thing at once so essential and so immaterial . It is something that calls upon such men as [I]0-i with an irresistible appeal . [I]0-i have figured it in [my]0-i last section by the symbol of [my]0-i destroyer , stark and swift , irrelevant to most human interests . Sometimes [I]0-i call this reality Science , sometimes [I]0-i call it Truth . But it is something [we]4263-we draw by pain and effort ont of the heart of life , that [we]4263-we disentangle and make clear . [Other men]2130-other men serve it , [I]0-i know , in art , in literature , in social invention , and see it in a thousand different figures , under a hundred names . [I]0-i see it always as austerity , as beauty . This thing [we]4263-we make clear is the heart of life . It is the one enduring thing . [Men]1661-men and [nations]3175-nations , epochs and civilisation pass each making its contribution [I]0-i do not know what it is , this something , except that it is supreme . It is , a something , a quality , an element , [one]696-one may find now in colours , now in norms , now in sounds , now in thoughts . It emerges from life with each year [one]696-one lives and feels , and generation by generation and age by age , but the how and why of it are all beyond the compass of [my]0-i mind .... Yet the full sense of it was with [me]0-i all that night as [I]0-i drove , lonely above the rush and murmur of [my]0-i engines , out upon [the weltering circle of [the sea]1422-the sea]4285-the weltering circle of the sea . Far out to the northeast there came the flicker of [a squadron of warships]4287-a squadron of warships waving white swords of light about the sky . [I]0-i kept them hull - down , and presently they were mere summer lightning over the watery edge of the globe .... [I]0-i fell into thought that was nearly formless , into doubts and dreams that have no words , and it seemed good to [me]0-i to drive ahead and on and or through the windy starlight , over the long black waves . It was morning and day before [I]0-i returned with [the four sick and starving journalists who had got permission to come with [me]0-i , up [the shining river]4289-the shining river]4288-the four sick and starving journalists who had got permission to come with me , up the shining river , and past [the old grey Tower ....]4290-the old grey tower .... [I]0-i recall the back views of [those journalists]4291-those journalists very distinctly , going with a certain damp weariness of movement , along [a side street]4292-a side street away from [the river]1421-the river . [They]4291-those journalists were [good men]4294-good men and bore [me]0-i no malice , and [they]4291-those journalists served [me]0-i up to the public in turgid degenerate [Kiplingese]349-kiplingese , as [a modest button on [the complacent stomach of [the Empire]4277-the empire]4296-the complacent stomach of the empire]4295-a modest button on the complacent stomach of the empire . Though as a matter of fact , X2 is n't intended for [the empire]4277-the empire , or indeed for the hands of [any European power]4299-any european power . [We]4300-we offered it to [[our]4300-we own people]4301-our own people first , but [they]4301-our own people would have nothing to do with [me]0-i , and [I]0-i have long since ceased to trouble much about such questions . [I]0-i have come to see [myself]0-i from the outside , [[my]0-i country]4302-my country from the outside - without illusions . [We]4300-we make and pass . [We]4300-we are all things that make and pass striving upon a hidden mission , out to [the open sea]4303-the open sea .
